question: Question_06
statement:
At what point on the interval $(0, \frac{\pi}2)$ does the tangent line
to the curve

\begin{align*}y = 3x + \sqrt{3}\cos (x) - \sin (x)\end{align*} have the smallest slope?
sols:
First we find an formula for the quantity we're minimizing: the slope of
the tangent line. This formula is the derivative of the function:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f'(x) = 3 - \sqrt{3} \sin x - \cos x\end{align*}

This is the formula we are minimizing, which we will now call
$\displaystyle g(x) = 3 - \sqrt{3} \sin x - \cos x$. Following our usual
procedure for finding maxima/minima, we take the derivative of
\emph{g(x)}, set it equal to zero, and solve for the critical points.

\begin{align*}g'(x) = -\sqrt{3}\cos x + \sin x\end{align*}

Setting equal to zero and solving gives:

\begin{align*}\sqrt{3} \cos x = \sin x\end{align*}

So we are looking for an angle where $\sin(x)$ is equal to
$\sqrt{3}\cos(x)$. There is no ``formula'' to solve this equation;
instead you have to use trig ratios and special triangles, or consult
the unit circle. On a 30-60-90 degree triangle, or at the angles 30 (in
radians: \emph{x = $\pi$/6}) and 60 (in radians: \emph{x = $\pi$/3}) on the unit
circle, $\sin(x)$ and $\cos(x)$ are related in a ratio of $1 : \sqrt{3}$
so these angles are our candidates. At these values we have

\begin{align*}\cos\left(\frac{\pi}6\right) = \frac{\sqrt{3}}2, \quad \sin\left(\frac{\pi}6\right) = \frac12\end{align*}

\begin{align*}\cos\left(\frac{\pi}3\right) = \frac12, \quad \sin\left(\frac{\pi}3\right) = \frac{\sqrt{3}}2\end{align*}

Hence \emph{x = $\pi$/3} is the solution of equation and hence our critical
point. We check if this point is indeed a minimum by performing the
first derivative test:

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& $(0, \pi/3)$ & $x = \pi/3$ & $(\pi/3, \pi/2)$\\
$\displaystyle g'(x)$ & - & 0 & +\\
$\displaystyle g(x)$ & decreasing & min & increasing\\
\end{longtable}

Hence the tangent line \emph{g(x)} has the smallest slope when \emph{x =
$\pi$/3}.

\emph{Note that we do not need to check the endpoints of the interval,
because neither is included in the domain.}
hints:
See the word ``smallest''? -{}- this is an optimization question. But
read carefully; what is being minimized here?

This question is asking you to find a minimum slope of a tangent line.
This means you first need to find a formula for the slope of the tangent
line (the derivative); \textbf{then} find the minimum value of this
expression.
